results.title: Peep-peep-peep
results.brief_description: Puppet animated film about the Wombles who live under Wimbledon Common in London. In this episode the Wombles discover a crude version of the telephone by using tins and string. Based on the children’s book series The Wombles by Elizabeth Beresford. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Peculiar galaxies
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
This episode discusses a peculiar type of galaxy called a Quasar. Quasars looked liked stars but did not have the same size, shape or spectrum as stars. They were extremely luminous and expanding away from us. Quasars are believed to be the cause of galaxies. Astronomers believe that the structure of a Quasar is an extremely bright nucleus of a galaxy and a central Black Hole which over time evolves into a “normal” galaxy.

results.title: Pearson Island
results.brief_description: Pearson Island, in the Great Australian Bight, supports a varied native fauna. Sea-lions live there permanently, and the sea birds include penguins, terns, oyster-catchers and Cape Barron geese. Saltbush and she-oak forest on higher ground have land birds and a native rat and wallaby extinct elsewhere. Commentary by Roger Cardwell.

results.title: Pearls in the north [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Oliver Howes
results.brief_description: Examines the pearling industry in the far north of Australia. After a post-war decline the industry now has a bright future. Nine luggers, from Broome, with Japanese and Malay crews, work the rich pearlshell beds. Shows diving techniques and a cultured pearl farm.

results.title: Pearls and savages (1921)
results.creator_credit: Stoll Film Co and Frank Hurley
results.brief_description: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. After World War 1, having filled the position as the first official photographer of the Australian war effort, Hurley became interested in Papua New Guinea. In December 1920, he left Australia to record the work of Anglican missions in Papua and to make “travelogue entertainment”. The result was this documentary, “Pearls and Savages” which was released in Sydney, in December 1921.

results.title: Peaches, pears and people
results.brief_description: Looks at the peach and pear industry in the Shepparton district, Victoria - from the initial cultivation of the crops to the final stages of production in the factory.

results.title: Peace in no man's land
results.brief_description: On the Western Front on Christmas Day 1915, British and German soldiers ceased fire and fraternized in the “no man’s land” between the trenches. Actual testimony letters are combined with photographs to create the atmosphere of comradeship of line soldiers who believed they were just doing their duty.

results.title: Peace and voices in the wilderness
results.brief_description: One of man’s continuing problems is to reconcile the difference between what life is like and what it ought to be like. Shows the idyllic and essentially peaceful nature of life in the wilderness. Contrasts these scenes with sounds of riot, assassination, and other indications of man’s crimes against man in order to stimulate discussion on the effects of and solutions to some of society’s major problems.
